metadata.title: Facile synthesis of DBU-based ionic liquids cooperated with ZnI<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> as catalysts for efficient cycloaddition of CO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> to epoxides under mild and solvent-free conditions

Facile synthesis of DBU-based ionic liquids cooperated with ZnI2 as catalysts for efficient cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides under mild and solvent-free conditions Chaokun Yang a 1 Mengshuai Liu b 1 Jiaxu Zhang a ⁎ Xin Wang a Yichen Jiang a Jianmin Sun a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China b College of Chemical Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, PR China College of Chemical Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao 266042 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to the paper. Graphical abstract Different DBU-based ionic liquids (DILs) were facilely synthesized by one-step neutralization and exhibited excellent catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides under mild and solvent-free conditions cooperating with ZnI2. The cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is an important reaction and has got increasing attention. In this work, a series of DBU-based ionic liquids (DILs) were synthesized via facile neutralization of superbase 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) with corresponding hydrogen bond donor acids, such as D(−)-tartaric acid (TA), malic acid (MA) and succinic acid (SA). The DILs cooperated with ZnI2 were first evaluated in detail for catalyzing the coupling reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO), and DIL-1 exhibited obviously enhanced catalytic activity under 80 °C, 3 MPa and solvent-free conditions. The effects of reaction parameters on the activity for propylene carbonate (PC) synthesis were thoroughly investigated, and a possible synergistic catalytic mechanism was proposed. The catalytic system reported here could be separated by simple centrifugation from the products after reaction and then reused efficiently. Moreover, the catalytic system showed the advantages of simple synthesis, high catalytic activity, low cost, and substrate versatility for CO2 conversion to cyclic carbonates. Keywords CO2 cycloaddition DBU-based ionic liquids Epoxide Cyclic carbonate 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) emission is commonly recognized as a primary factor to global warming [1], simultaneously, CO2 is an abundant, non-toxic and renewable C1 resource. And the reasonable utilization of CO2 has become a hot topic for researchers. The 100% atom-economic cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides for producing the five-membered cyclic carbonates is one of the most promising endeavors in the CO2 conversion fields (Scheme 1 ) [2]. Moreover, the cyclic carbonates can be widely used as polar aprotic solvents, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, intermediates in the manufacture of fine chemicals [3], constituents of oils and paints, and raw materials in the synthesis of polycarbonates [4]. Nowadays, a huge surge of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic systems, including metal-oxides [5], alkali metal salts [6,7], metal–salen complexes [8,9], ammonium or phosphonium salts [3,10], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [11,12], and various ionic liquids [13–15], have been developed for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. However, many of these catalytic systems are limited in industrial application because of high cost, complicated synthetic process, harsh reaction conditions or limited reusability. Recently, Sun’s group [2,16–18] and O. Hauenstein et al. [19] have reported that Zn as Lewis acid could activate epoxides by bonding O atom of epoxides to promote the ring-opening reaction, which is generally regarded as the rate-determining step towards the whole CO2 cycloaddition reaction to epoxides [20]. Alternatively, hydrogen bond donor groups such as amino [18,21–23], carboxyl [24] and hydroxyl group [25] were able to form hydrogen bond to epoxides, then accelerating the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Furthermore, the combined actions of hydrogen bond donor with Lewis acid species were attempted to reduce energy barrier of the ring-opening of epoxides. Inspired by these, herein we develop a new catalytic system, i.e. DBU-based ionic liquids/ZnI2, in which the multifunctional species of the amino group, hydroxyl group and Zn species were incorporated. Attractively, the DBU-based ionic liquids were facilely synthesized via neutralization of superbase 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) with a series of common acids as shown in Scheme 2 . The facile synthesis of catalysts would be anticipated to amplify their potential application towards the efficient CO2 cycloaddition to produce cyclic carbonates. And the correlation of catalyst structure-activity was investigated, the reaction parameters, such as temperature, CO2 pressure as well as reaction time were thoroughly optimized. Moreover, the catalyst reusability and substrate versatility were studied. Based on the experimental results, a feasible reaction mechanism was proposed. The developed DILs/ZnI2 catalytic system possesses facile synthesis, low cost and excellent activity together with simple separation for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, which contribute to the potentially alternative catalysts for effective CO2 utilization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and instruments D(−)-tartaric acid (99%) was purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) (99%), malic acid (99%), succinic acid (99%), ZnI2 and epoxides (99%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Co., Alcohol was purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Carbon dioxide with 99.99% purity was provided from Harbin Qinghua Industrial gases Co., Ltd. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on Bruker 400 M nuclear resonance spectrometer. FT-IR spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR Spectrometer by using anhydrous KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves were obtained using NETZSCH STA449F3 simultaneous thermogravimetric analyzer under the conditions of 30–800 °C, N2 atmosphere with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. GC analyses were performed on an Agilent GC-7890A equipped with capillary column (Agilent 19091J-413) and a flame ionization detector. 2.2 Synthesis of DBU-based ionic liquids (DILs) Different DBU-based ionic liquids (DILs) were prepared via facile neutralization of superbase 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) with D(−)-tartaric acid (TA), malic acid (MA) and succinic acid (SA), respectively. The synthetic procedure and structures of corresponding DILs were shown in Scheme 3 . Taken the DIL-1 synthesis as example, a mixture of D(−)-tartaric acid (2.2 mmol) and DBU (4.4 mmol) with molar ratio of 1:2 and alcohol (50 mL) were charged into a flask, and the flask was then heated at 70 °C for 4 h with vigorous stirring. Then the mixture was cooled down to room temperature, and alcohol solvent was completely removed by rotary evaporation to obtain DIL-1. The synthetic procedures for other DILs were similar to that of DIL-1 with the same molar ratio. The main differences were the corresponding MA and SA were used to replace TA. 2.3 Catalytic procedure for CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides In a typical run, 0.22 mmol DILs and the corresponding amount of co-catalyst ZnI2 were added into a 50 mL high pressure stainless-steel autoclave that equipped with a magnetic stirring bar. Then 34.5 mmol propylene oxide (PO) was successively added into the autoclave. Next, the autoclave was heated to a preset temperature of 120 °C using an oil bath. When the temperature comes to a steady state, CO2 was finally introduced to 2.0 MPa. The autoclave was heated at a certain temperature for a designated period of time. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, and the remaining CO2 was released slowly. The product was diluted with ethyl acetate and analyzed on GC, the DILs/ZnI2 catalysts readily precipitated from the solution simultaneously. Then, the DILs/ZnI2 catalysts were separated by centrifugation, and washed by ethyl acetate three times after a run and reused for the next run without addition of DILs or ZnI2. For comparison, 2,3-butanediol (BD) was mechanically mixed with DBU at the same ratio for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterizations of DBU-based ionic liquids (DILs) In order to confirm the structure and thermostability of DILs, TLC (Thin Layer Chromatography), 1H NMR, FT-IR and TG were performed. There was no shift of DIL-1 on TLC, indicating that DIL-1 has a strong polarity, which meant the obtained DIL-1 is a possibly formed salt. Furthermore, according to 1H NMR spectra of TA and DIL-1, as shown in Fig. 1 , the COOH (δ 12.69) of TA disappeared after the synthesis process, indicating the H of COOH reacted with DBU. FT-IR spectra and TG curves of DIL-1 were given in Fig. 2 . The peak at 3544–3116 cm−1 became broader after the formation of DIL-1 (Fig. 2A), which might be ascribed to overlap of CH2 stretching vibration with the new formed NH groups in DIL-1 structure. As shown in Fig. 2B, after neutralizing of organic base DBU, DIL-1 showed the better thermostability obviously, suggesting DILs could be applied as catalyst for the CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides that was conducted at 120 °C or much lower temperature. TA: 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 12.69 (s, 2H), 5.08 (s, 2H), 4.31 (s, 2H). DBU: 1H NMR (400 MHz, Chloroform-d) δ 3.21 (t, J = 5.6 Hz, 2H), 3.18–3.08 (m, 4H), 2.40–2.24 (m, 2H), 1.73 (p, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 1.66–1.44 (m, 6H). DIL-1: 1H NMR (400 MHz, Chloroform-d) δ 4.28 (s, 2H), 3.65 (q, J = 7.0 Hz, 6H), 3.41 (dt, J = 17.4, 5.7 Hz, 13H), 2.89–2.74 (m, 4H), 1.95 (p, J = 5.8 Hz, 4H), 1.80–1.54 (m, 13H), 1.18 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 8H). The peaks at 1.18 and 3.65 were the characteristic peak of CH2CH3, which belongs to the residuary alcohol. 3.2 The screening of catalysts Firstly, different catalysts and components of DILs/ZnX2(X = Cl, Br, I) were screened for the model cycloaddition of CO2 to PO, the results obtained were summarized in Table 1 . There was no product when DBU or TA as catalyst alone (entries 1 and 2). Trace product was detected with ZnI2 (entry 3). And mechanical mixture of DBU-TA also cannot provide the enhanced activity (entry 4). With separate DIL-1 catalyst, 19% PC yield and 98% selectivity could be afforded under the employed conditions (entry 5). When combined DIL-1 with ZnI2, the catalytic activities were improved at different mole ratios of DIL-1 and ZnI2 (entries 6–8). With increasing the mole ratio from 1:0.5 to 1:1.5, the PC yield enhanced from 41% to 77% under the condition of 100 °C, 2 MPa for 2 h, because the increased Lewis acid Zn species could cooperate with DIL-1 to accelerate the epoxide activation then promoted the coupling reaction. While further increasing of the mole ratio to 1:2, the PC yield decreased to 60% (entries 9). This may be attributed to excess iodide ions, as hydrogen bonding acceptor, which limited the function of OH and NH groups for epoxides activation [13]. Thus, the subsequent reactions were checked at DILs/ZnI2 mole ratio of 1:1.5. Additionally, various ZnX2(X = Cl, Br, I) (entries 8, 10–11) and DILs with different constituents (entries 8, 12–14) were also tested, and it was found that the catalytic activities were distinctly affected by halogen anion of ZnX2 and structure of DILs. The activity decreased in the order of I− > Br− > Cl−, this was closely related to their nucleophilicity. Similar results were evidenced by Wang et al. using tetrabutylammonium halogens catalyst [26]. Compared with the stronger intermolecular hydrogen bonds formed between DILs with Br− and Cl− anions in the catalyst systems, I− showed the best leaving capability and was more inclined to complete nucleophilic attack for epoxy-ring opening, which will be discussed further in the subsequent mechanism detection. Besides, DIL-1 exhibited better activity than DIL-2, DIL-3 and mechanical DBU-BD (entries 8, 12–14). With similar structures of DILs, the numbers of OH in the catalyst affected the catalytic activity remarkedly. The catalytic activity enhanced with more OH in the order of DIL-1> DIL-2> DIL-3. Although OH groups exist in the DBU-BD catalysts, no NH was formed in the catalytic system, indicating important synergistic effect of NH, OH and ZnI2 for catalyzing the cycloaddition reaction. As the previous studies suggested that hydrogen-bond donor such as OH and NH and Lewis acid Zn2+ could activate epoxides substrate [16,18,25], thus, the co-existence of functional OH, NH and Zn2+ in our studied DILs/ZnI2 catalysts synergistically activated PO, which was a crucial step in the CO2 coupling reaction with epoxides [18]. The catalytic system DILs/ZnI2 with molar ratio of 1:1.5 was chosen for further investigation towards the cyclic carbonate synthesis from CO2 and epoxides. 3.3 The optimization of reaction parameters for CO2 cycloaddition reaction With DIL-1/ZnI2 catalysts at optimal molar ratio of 1:1.5, the influence of different reaction parameters on PC synthesis was examined. As shown in Fig. 3 A, reaction temperature has a positive effect on the reaction. The PC yield increased with the reaction temperature from 80 °C to 120 °C, which was resulted from the intrinsic process that elevated temperature facilitating more effective collisions between the active species of catalyst and the substrate molecules in the cycloaddition reaction [27]. At 120 °C, the PC yield reached 99%, and the selectivity to the desired PC product was also perfect. Satisfyingly, at even the temperature of 80 °C or lower to 60 °C, PO was also quantitively conversed to the desired product PC only at the expense of long reaction time of 5 h and 8 h (Table 3). Fig. 3B shows the effect of CO2 pressure on the cycloaddition reaction at 120 °C. When the pressure was enhanced from 1.0 MPa to 2.0 MPa, the yield sharply increased from 57% to 95%. The initial increase of CO2 pressure resulted in the enhancement of CO2 concentration in the reaction phase, thus improving the PC yield [28]. Further improvement of CO2 pressure to 3.0 MPa, as lower PO concentration existed in the reactive phase, thus, higher CO2 pressure did not result in the enhancement of the product yield. Fig. 3C indicates that the PC yield increased with reaction time. Specifically, PC yield increased dramatically from 48% for 1.0 h to 97% within 2.0 h. Further prolonging reaction time, the product yield did not obviously change, then 2.0 h is enough for the cycloaddition reaction. Therefore, the optimized reaction parameters were 120 °C, 3.0 MPa and 2.0 h. Compared to other reported work (Table 2 ), DIL-1/ZnI2 exhibited the advantages of lower catalyst loading, reasonable CO2 pressure and mild temperature for effective CO2 cycloaddition to propylene oxide. Noticeably, the DIL-1catalyst was facilely synthesized, which was attractive for application. 3.4 Reusability of DIL-1/ZnI2 catalytic system The recyclability of a catalyst is also a crucial factor in practical application. In order to examine the recyclability of the DIL-1/ZnI2 catalytic system, the cycloaddition reaction was repeated under the optimum reaction conditions (120 °C, 3.0 MPa, 2.0 h). After each run, the precipitated DIL-1/ZnI2 catalysts could be separated by centrifugation, and washed by ethyl acetate three times after a run and reused for the next run. As shown in Fig. 4 A, initially, PC yield did not obviously change, then decreased at the fourth and fifth cycles, this was possibly resulted from the slight loss of DIL-1/ZnI2 during the transfer or separation process. In order to analyze the possible reasons for the decrease of catalytic activity, leaching experiment was conducted. After the three runs, the DIL-1/ZnI2 catalysts were stirred with PO substrate for 2 h, then the catalysts were separated and the filtrate was used as the catalyst for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, and only trace product was detected, proving that no leaching of Zn metal and ionic liquids were observed in the reaction mixture. Moreover, to monitor the activity of the recycled DIL-1/ZnI2 under the same condition, PO addition was quantitatively reduced to keep the catalysts concentration in the 6th cycle the same to the first run, and 94% PC yield and 97% selectivity were obtained again, evidencing that the decrease of PC yield was resulted from the loss of catalysts during the transfer or separation process. Fig. 4B shows FT-IR spectra of DIL-1/ZnI2 before and after catalysis. After the reaction, the structure of spent DIL-1/ZnI2 was almost the same with fresh catalysts excepted for a new appeared peak at 1790 cm−1, which indicating that DIL-1 could chemical absorption of CO2 to form the carbamate [13], while the new formed carbamate didn’t affect the activity of DIL-1/ZnI2. According to the TG curves of fresh and recycled DIL-1/ZnI2 (Fig. 4C), the main difference was resulted from the stripping of CO2 from the new formed carbamate. All that proved the excellent recycle performance of DIL-1/ZnI2 catalysts. 3.5 Cycloaddition of CO2 with various epoxides over DIL-1/ZnI2 catalysts In order to study the versatility of DIL-1/ZnI2 catalytic system, the catalytic conversion of CO2 with different epoxide substrates, including propylene oxide, 1,2-epoxybutane, epichlorohydrin and styrene oxide were investigated. As shown in Table 3 , all terminal epoxides could be converted to the corresponding products with excellent conversion and selectivity under 120 °C, 2.0 h, 3.0 MPa. Even excellent catalytic performance could be kept even at the mild temperature of 80 °C for 5 h. 3.6 Plausible reaction mechanism Based on the pioneering works [2,33,34] and our experimental results, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed in Scheme 4 . First, Lewis acid Zn2+ could coordinate with oxygen atom of epoxides to form Zn–O adduct. Additionally, according to Table 1, both OH and NH groups could influence the cycloaddition reaction positively by bonding with oxygen atom of epoxides to form hydrogen bonds. These two efforts produced a new activated adduct (Step 1), which was reactively lower electron concentration than epoxides. Meanwhile, the nucleophilic I− attacked to less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of activated epoxides, thus, the ring of terminal epoxides was opened to form an oxyanion intermediate (Step 2), which was stabilized by Zn and hydrogen bond donor species. When CO2 participated in cycloaddition reaction, which was activated by basic N in the catalyst (Step 3) [35]. Additionally, Fig. 5 demonstrated the FT-IR spectra of fresh DIL-1 and DIL-1 exposed to CO2, the main difference between the two spectra is the peak at 1790 cm−1, which is ascribed to activated carbomate. Next, the activated CO2 interacted with the ring-opened adduct to form cyclic carbonate (Step 4). Finally, intramolecular ring-closure process was proceeded to release the cyclic carbonate product, meanwhile, the Lewis acid Zn2+, nucleophilic group I− and DIL-1 were regenerated (Step 5). Hence, hydroxyl, amino group and Zn2+ cooperately activated epoxides, I− promoted the ring-opening, at the same time DIL-1 activated CO2, these multifunctional DIL-1/ZnI2 catalytic system facilitated the CO2 cycloaddition reaction smoothly and efficiently. 4 Conclusions Multifunctional DILs catalysts were synthesized by facile method and cooperated with ZnI2 as catalysts for CO2 conversion into various cyclic carbonates under solvent-free conditions. In the cycloaddition reaction, 99% PC yield and excellent selectivity were obtained under mild temperature of 80 °C for 5 h and 3 MPa even at 60 °C within a longer reaction time of 8 h, which was attributed to multiple activations of epoxides with Zn, amino and hydroxyl synergistically. Cooperatively, the basic N atoms in the catalyst benefited the activation of CO2. Furthermore, compared with other similar catalytic systems, the reported DILs/ZnI2 catalytic system exhibited promisingly alternative in CO2 conversion into useful cyclic carbonate under mild reaction conditions without additional organic solvent for its facile synthesis, high efficiency, easy separation and excellent reusability. coredata.dc:description: The cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is an important reaction and has got increasing attention. In this work, a series of DBU-based ionic liquids (DILs) were synthesized via facile neutralization of superbase 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) with corresponding hydrogen bond donor acids, such as D(−)-tartaric acid (TA), malic acid (MA) and succinic acid (SA). The DILs cooperated with ZnI2 were first evaluated in detail for catalyzing the coupling reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO), and DIL-1 exhibited obviously enhanced catalytic activity under 80 °C, 3 MPa and solvent-free conditions. The effects of reaction parameters on the activity for propylene carbonate (PC) synthesis were thoroughly investigated, and a possible synergistic catalytic mechanism was proposed. The catalytic system reported here could be separated by simple centrifugation from the products after reaction and then reused efficiently. Moreover, the catalytic system showed the advantages of simple synthesis, high catalytic activity, low cost, and substrate versatility for CO2 conversion to cyclic carbonates.
coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of DBU-based ionic liquids cooperated with ZnI2 as catalysts for efficient cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides under mild and solvent-free conditions
